The reason for declining a gift is not the gift's sentimental value to the patient or, in this case, to this patient's deceased husband.

E) INCORRECT:

Physicians should avoid accepting gifts that are very personal or intimate in nature, very large, and/or potentially valuable. Furthermore, a physician should not convey the impression that a gift may lead to preferential treatment in the future.
questions.hint: The gift offered to this physician is likely to have high monetary value.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his friends because of a 1-hour history of shortness of breath and squeezing chest pain. They were at a party where cocaine was consumed. A diagnosis of acute myocardial infarction is made. The physician stabilizes the patient and transfers him to the inpatient unit. Six hours later, his wife arrives at the emergency department and requests information about her husband's condition. Which of the following is the most appropriate action by the physician?

choices.text: Obtain authorization from the patient to release information
Inform the wife about her husband's condition
Consult the hospital ethics committee
Request the patient's durable power of attorney document
Ask the wife for a marriage certificate

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

All information about a patient's health, even his location in the hospital, is confidential and must not be shared with anyone outside of the patient's direct health care team without explicit consent. If the patient were unconscious or otherwise incapacitated and someone was able to identify him by name, it may be acceptable to tell this person the patient's location and general health status. However, this patient is most likely able to give his consent and must be consulted before any information about him is shared.

B) INCORRECT:

All information about a patient's health is confidential and must not be shared with anyone outside of his direct health care team, even the patient's spouse or other family members, without his explicit consent. In an emergency situation or when the patient is incapacitated, it is appropriate to disclose information about a patient's general health status and location in the health care facility for anyone who asks for them by name; however, information about a patient's condition should not be shared without consent.

C) INCORRECT:

A hospital ethics committee consult is a useful step in the management of patients who lack decision-making capacity if there is conflict among family members or surrogates regarding goals of care. There is no indication that this patient cannot make decisions about his health care.

D) INCORRECT:

A durable power of attorney for health care is a legal document that grants a surrogate the right to make medical decisions on behalf of a patient should the patient become incapacitated. There is no indication that this patient cannot make decisions about his health care. Furthermore, power of attorney documents do not by themselves allow access to confidential patient information without a specific clause granting such access to surrogate decision makers.

E) INCORRECT:

Proof that the woman is the patient's wife does not give her a right to access the patient's confidential information without his consent.
questions.hint: A physician is ethically and legally obliged to keep a patient's medical information confidential.

questions.text: A 41-year-old homeless man comes to the emergency department because of progressively worsening pain in his left leg. His past medical history is unknown. He emigrated from China 2 years ago and does not have health insurance or money to pay for any medical care. He appears dirty and is malodorous. The left lower extremity is pale. Which of the following is the most appropriate action by the physician?

choices.text: Transfer the patient to a larger hospital that can provide him with medical care at no cost.
Offer the patient consultation on eligibility for emergency Medicaid coverage.
Provide stabilizing treatment to the maximum amount allotted by the hospital care assistance program.
Offer the patient enrollment in a county healthcare assistance program for low-income patients.
Perform a medical screening examination and provide stabilizing treatment if needed.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Transferring the patient to another hospital is appropriate if the hospital is not equipped or staffed to properly evaluate and treat a patient's condition. There is no evidence to suggest that this is the case here. Moreover, acute limb ischemia is a time-sensitive condition; transferring the patient would inappropriately delay definitive diagnosis and treatment, placing him at unacceptable risk for permanent morbidity.

B) INCORRECT:

The patient's eligibility for Medicaid coverage should not dictate further diagnostic or therapeutic steps. Though offering consultation to assess this patient's eligibility for Medicaid coverage is appropriate once the patient's condition is stabilized, doing so at this time would inappropriately delay treatment and place the patient's health at serious risk.

C) INCORRECT:

Many hospitals provide care at discounted or no cost for patients who are unable to pay for medical care. This is most often the case with treatment for elective or chronic health conditions. However, this patient's presentation is consistent with an acute medical emergency. The appropriate diagnostic and therapeutic steps should be taken regardless of the terms of this hospital's care assistance program. After the patient is stabilized, an appropriate plan for providing ongoing treatment can be determined based on the hospital's care assistance program.

D) INCORRECT:

Once the patient is stabilized, it is appropriate to assist him in finding healthcare coverage (e.g., through a county healthcare assistance program for low-income patients). However, as he is currently experiencing a medical emergency, the highest priority should be the evaluation and stabilization of his condition.

E) CORRECT:

According to the Emergency Medical Treatment and Labor Act (EMTALA), any hospital with an emergency department is required to screen for emergency medical conditions if requested and, if such a condition exists, provide treatment until that condition is stabilized. Failure to diagnose and treat acute lower extremity ischemia places the patient at unacceptable risk for extremity infarction and, ultimately, loss of leg function. The EMTALA defines an emergency medical condition as a medical condition that manifests with acute symptoms (including pain and labor contractions) that are sufficiently severe to (i) place the health of the individual or unborn child in serious jeopardy, (ii) seriously impair bodily functions, or (iii) cause serious dysfunction of an organ or body part.
questions.hint: This patient's acute-onset, unilateral lower extremity pain and pallor (two of the six Ps) are concerning for acute lower extremity ischemia.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man comes to the office for a routine health maintenance examination. During the examination, he expresses concerns about not wanting to become a father. He has been sexually active and monogamous with his wife for the past 5 years, and they inconsistently use condoms for contraception. He tells the physician that he would like to undergo vasectomy. His wife is also a patient under the care of the physician and during her last appointment, she expressed concerns over being prescribed any drugs that could affect her fertility because she would like to conceive soon. Which of the following is the most appropriate action by the physician regarding this patient's wish to undergo vasectomy?

choices.text: Insist that the patient returns with his wife to discuss the risks and benefits of the procedure together
Explain the procedure's benefits, alternatives, and potential complications
Refer the patient to a psychotherapist to discuss his reluctance to have children
Call the patient's wife to obtain her consent for the procedure
Discourage the patient from undergoing the procedure because his wife wants children

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

It would be preferable for the patient and his wife to reach a consensus on his decision to undergo a vasectomy, and for both to be aware of the risks and benefits of the procedure. However, it is ultimately the decision of the patient (and not a spouse) to undergo such a procedure.

B) CORRECT:

This patient must understand the benefits, alternatives, and potential complications of undergoing a vasectomy in order to provide informed consent. This conversation should explore the patient's reasons for undergoing permanent sterilization. Although the wife's consent for this procedure is not required, the physician should encourage the patient to discuss his decision with his wife, whose wish to conceive in the near future could factor into the patient's decision.

C) INCORRECT:

It is inappropriate to refer a patient to a psychotherapist to discuss their request to undergo sterilization because the decision to not have children is a personal one and is not pathological. However, it might be helpful for patients to discuss the matter with a skilled counselor if they have expressed distress about their decision.

D) INCORRECT:

Only the patient can provide informed consent for the procedure, and the physician has an ethical and legal obligation to keep the patient's medical information confidential. It is ultimately the decision of the patient (and not a spouse) to undergo such a procedure.

E) INCORRECT:

Although it is reasonable to inquire about the patient's understanding of how the procedure will affect his wife, it is inappropriate to discourage the patient from undergoing the procedure. While it is preferable for a couple to reach a consensus about sterilization procedures, it is ultimately the decision of the patient (and not a spouse) to undergo such a procedure.
questions.hint: This patient has full decision-making capacity with the ability to evaluate the benefits and risks of the procedure.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a 1-week history of fever, throat pain, and difficulty swallowing. Head and neck examination shows an erythematous pharynx with purulent exudates overlying the palatine tonsils. Microscopic examination of a throat culture shows purple, spherical bacteria arranged in chains. Treatment with amoxicillin is initiated. A day later, a physician colleague from another department approaches the physician in the lobby of the hospital and asks about this patient, saying, “Did you see him? What does he have? He’s someone I play football with and he hasn’t come to play for the past 5 days. I’m worried about him.” Which of the following is the most appropriate action by the physician?

choices.text: Inform the colleague that she cannot divulge any information about the patient
Inform the colleague that he should ask the patient's attending physician
Tell her colleague that she cannot tell him the diagnosis but that his friend was treated with antibiotics
Tell her colleague the patient's case file number so he can look it up himself
Ask the colleague to meet in her office so they can discuss the patient in private

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This response maintains the patient's privacy in accordance with the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act. Privileged health information, in this case, the patient's diagnosis and course of treatment, should not be disclosed to third parties without the patient's consent. Scenarios that do not require this consent include emergency care or consultation with another treating physician. These conditions do not apply here.

B) INCORRECT:

This response avoids the colleague's concern. Moreover, there is no indication that the attending physician has permission to disclose confidential health information about the patient.

C) INCORRECT:

The release of even partial information about a patient to another individual qualifies as a breach of doctor-patient confidentiality. Verbal or written consent from a patient is required before releasing any information to any individuals who are not directly involved in the patient's medical care, including a physician's colleague. Sharing information about which drug was prescribed is a violation of the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act.

D) INCORRECT:

Viewing a patient's medical record for reasons unrelated to direct medical care violates the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act and is never appropriate.

E) INCORRECT:

Patient information should not be discussed in a public area (e.g., the hospital lobby). Moreover, verbal or written consent from a patient is required before releasing information to any individuals who are not directly involved in their medical care, including a physician's colleague. Sharing information at this time, even in a private setting, is a violation of the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act.
questions.hint: The physician's colleague is not directly involved in this patient's care.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his friends 30 minutes after falling down a flight of stairs. His friends report that they were at a college party, where he drank large amounts of alcohol. His friends also say that the patient usually drinks at least two beers every night and more than that on the weekends. The patient is aggressive and restless. Examination shows tenderness to palpation and swelling of his right lower leg. An x-ray of the right leg shows a lower tibial shaft fracture. The physician recommends overnight observation and surgery the following morning. The patient refuses the suggested treatment because he is convinced that his leg is not fractured. He requests immediate discharge. Otherwise, he says, he will call his lawyer and sue the entire medical staff involved in his care. Which of the following is the most appropriate response by the physician?

choices.text: “I am sorry but treatment is medically indicated and I am obligated to obtain consent from your parents if you do not agree to the treatment.”
"I acknowledge that you want to go home but would like to ask some more questions first. Have you ever felt you should cut down on your drinking?"
"You can leave the hospital after signing a self-discharge against medical advice form."
"I respect your choice. Let's talk about the alternative treatment options and whether you would agree to one of them."
"I understand that you want to go home but you have to stay at the hospital for as long as you are intoxicated."
"You will be discharged if you wish but I will have to inform your parents of this incident."

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Consent from a legal guardian or a person with the power of attorney must be obtained before treating a patient with permanently impaired decision-making capacity. In the event of a life-threatening condition, a physician may initiate treatment of a patient against his or her will, if that patient's decision-making capacity is impaired. However, this patient's condition is not immediately life-threatening and his impaired decision-making capacity is likely to be temporary. Therefore, it would be more appropriate to wait until he was sober to make a definitive decision.

B) INCORRECT:

Questioning a patient about cutting down on drinking is the first of the CAGE questions, which are used to screen for problematic drinking. This question would be appropriate during a follow-up evaluation. However, considering this patient's acute intoxication, it would be unlikely to lead to a productive dialogue.

C) INCORRECT:

A patient with intact decision-making capacity may always choose to leave the hospital. However, this patient's intoxication reduces his capacity to fully understand the consequences of his medical condition. Discharging an intoxicated patient might endanger the patient's health and also have untoward legal consequences for the responsible physician.

D) INCORRECT:

Informing patients about alternative treatment options is crucial to informed consent. However, this patient's intoxication reduces his capacity to fully understand the consequences of his medical condition and to rationally consider different treatment options.

E) CORRECT:

This patient is able to state his choice (no treatment), but his understanding, appreciation of the relevant facts, and ability to describe the reasoning for his decision are most likely impaired by acute alcohol intoxication. As the patient currently does not have decision-making capacity and discharge would seriously endanger his health, he should remain at the hospital until sober. If a patient's decision-making capacity is temporarily impaired (e.g., because of alcohol intoxication) and their condition is not life-threatening but requires hospitalization, admission and reassessment of the decision when the impairment has subsided are necessary.

In patients with full decision-making capacity, an informed decision must generally be respected. There are exceptional situations in which the patient's decision may be disregarded, for instance, when refusing treatment endangers others (e.g., active tuberculosis infection).

F) INCORRECT:

A patient with intact decision-making capacity may always leave the emergency department at his own request. However, this patient's intoxication reduces his capacity to fully understand the consequences of his medical condition. Furthermore, the physician should not inform the patient's parents of the incident, as that would be a breach of patient confidentiality and the patient is ≥ 18 years of age.
questions.hint: The treating physician has the responsibility to determine the patient's decision-making capacity, which consists of the ability to understand the information provided, appreciate the relevant facts, communicate one's choice, and describe the reasoning for one's decision.

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department after being involved in a motor vehicle accident in which he was a restrained passenger. He is confused and appears anxious. His pulse is 131/min, respirations are 29/min, and blood pressure is 95/49 mm Hg. Physical examination shows ecchymosis over the upper abdomen, with tenderness to palpation over the left upper quadrant. There is no guarding or rigidity. Abdominal ultrasound shows free intraperitoneal fluid and a splenic rupture. Intravenous fluids and vasopressors are administered. A blood transfusion and exploratory laparotomy are scheduled. The patient's mother arrives and insists that her son should not receive a blood transfusion because he is a Jehovah's Witness. The physician proceeds with the blood transfusion regardless of the mother's wishes. The physician's behavior is an example of which of the following principles of medical ethics?

choices.text: Justice
Nonmaleficence
Beneficence
Informed consent
Autonomy

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In medical ethics, justice refers to treating patients fairly and equitably, i.e., treatment is determined by the patient's specific medical needs (in contrast to treating all patients the same way). Although treatment is provided according to this patient's needs, there is a more appropriate term to describe the principle underlying this physician's decision not to follow the mother's wishes.

B) INCORRECT:

Nonmaleficence is the medical ethical principle of avoiding patient injury or suffering (“Do no harm.”). An example of nonmaleficence is deciding not to perform a procedure that might put a patient at risk. This principle may be outweighed in certain situations by the benefits of “harming” the patient (e.g., in most surgeries). Although there are potential risks associated with blood transfusions (e.g., transfusion reactions), this physician has decided to continue with the treatment, thereby not following the principle of nonmaleficence.

C) CORRECT:

This physician's actions demonstrate beneficence, which refers to acting in the best interest of the patient. Beneficence may conflict with patient or guardian autonomy. It is appropriate to treat a child whose guardian refuses lifesaving treatment for them. However, when adult patients refuse lifesaving treatment for themselves based on religious or other beliefs, and they understand the consequences of forgoing treatment, their decision should be accepted in order to respect patient autonomy.

D) INCORRECT:

Informed consent is usually required for procedures such as blood transfusions. This physician proceeded with the blood transfusion despite the patient's mother's lack of consent. However, his decision is appropriate, because the patient is in a life-threatening situation.

E) INCORRECT:

Autonomy refers to a patient or guardian's right to make decisions about whether or not to undergo treatment. Because this physician has not respected the decision of the patient's mother to refuse blood transfusion, the principle of autonomy has not been followed.
questions.hint: The physician's decision to perform blood transfusion is made in a situation that is life-threatening for the patient.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of a 3-day history of fatigue and bloody stools. Her temperature is 36°C (96.8°F), pulse is 112/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 102/65 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no other abnormalities. The abdomen is soft, and bowel sounds are normal. Rectal examination shows bright red blood. Her hemoglobin concentration is 8 g/dL, leukocyte count is 8000/mm3, and platelet count is 305,000/mm3. Intravenous fluid resuscitation is begun, blood is sent for type and crossmatch, and a transfusion of 1 unit of packed red blood cells is planned. She is admitted to the hospital with a diagnosis of diverticular bleeding and a gastroenterology consult is requested. To facilitate claims payment, a person with a verified health plan identification number from the patient's health insurance company contacts the physician supervising the patient's care and asks, “How long do you think this patient will be in the hospital?” The patient records include a note by the gastroenterologist that the patient should remain in the hospital for at least 3 days. Which of the following responses by the physician is most appropriate?

choices.text: "Could you send in a request via electronic mail? I am not allowed to share patient information with you on the telephone."
"She will be receiving at least one blood transfusion. It is too early to know how long she will be in the hospital."
"I anticipate that the patient will be in the hospital for at least 3 days."
"I need a consent release form signed by the patient before I can disclose any information."

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

HIPAA rules do not forbid the disclosure of information to a covered entity over the phone as long as the covered entity's identity can be verified through a reasonable technical or administrative safeguard (e.g., a person from the patient's health insurance company is verified by the health plan identification number).

B) INCORRECT:

According to the HIPAA privacy rule, disclosure of PHI should be limited to the minimum amount necessary to perform a particular task. In this case, the patient's health insurance company requested information on the expected duration of the hospital stay but did not ask for information about the exact treatment of the patient. Therefore, mentioning that the patient requires a blood transfusion violates the HIPAA privacy rule. Furthermore, withholding information from the health insurance company about the expected duration of hospital stay is also a subject of concern.

C) CORRECT:

According to the HIPAA privacy rule, access to and disclosure of PHI must be limited to the minimum necessary to fulfill the intended function for which it was requested (permitted information disclosure). In this case, the intended function is to facilitate claims payment, which is covered under Permitted Uses and Disclosures in HIPAA, and the patient's health insurance company only requested information on the duration of hospitalization for this purpose. This response is most appropriate because it provides the requested information and nothing beyond that.

D) INCORRECT:

According to the HIPAA privacy rule, limited disclosure of PHI to a health care insurance company is allowed without requesting consent from the patient. Information about the duration of hospitalization used to facilitate claim payments can be released without patient consent, so a consent form is not necessary.
questions.hint: When a covered entity (e.g., health plan, health care clearinghouse) requests access to protected health information (PHI), the minimum necessary requirement of the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA) requires hospitals and health care providers to limit access to and disclosure of PHI to what is necessary to accomplish a particular task.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman with terminal ovarian cancer comes to the emergency department because of abdominal pain and distention for the past 2 days. Three weeks ago, an abdominal CT scan showed ovarian metastases surrounding her superior rectum. At the time, she declined a proximal colostomy and provided a written advance directive that designated medical power of attorney to her eldest daughter in the event that she lacked the capacity to make medical decisions. Today, an abdominal x-ray shows a large bowel obstruction. The patient appears lethargic and thin. On mental status examination, she is alert and cooperative. She expresses that she does not want to receive any lifesaving procedures. She accurately describes her medical history and understands the consequences of her decision. The patient's eldest daughter, who is in the emergency department, says that she wants her mother to receive all necessary measures to stay alive. Which of the following is the most appropriate action by the physician?

choices.text: Follow the eldest daughter's wishes
Ask the patient to reconsider her decision
Discharge the patient against medical advice
Obtain a psychiatric consultation
Follow the patient's orally expressed wishes

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The patient's eldest daughter, the medical power of attorney designated by the patient, makes healthcare-related decisions if the patient does not have decision-making capacity. In this situation, however, the patient's decision-making is not compromised. Therefore, it is not appropriate to follow her eldest daughter's wishes at this time.

B) INCORRECT:

The physician should not ask the patient to reconsider her decision because she still has decision-making capacity, even if the patient's wishes are different from the wishes of the medical power of attorney she designated. Furthermore, the patient's current decision is consistent with the decision she made 3 weeks earlier to not have a colostomy. Therefore, the patient's decision should be respected.

C) INCORRECT:

Discharging the patient against medical advice would not be appropriate, because the patient has not asked to be discharged. Rather, she has requested that lifesaving procedures are avoided. Symptomatic treatment can still be provided in this situation.

D) INCORRECT:

Obtaining a psychiatric consultation is appropriate if the patient has symptoms of depression, and it would help to assess whether depression is influencing the patient's decisions. Because there is no indication that this patient is depressed and that depression is affecting her decision to decline lifesaving treatment, there is no need to obtain a psychiatric consultation.

E) CORRECT:

In accordance with the ethical principle of autonomy, the patient's orally expressed wishes should be respected if the patient has decision-making capacity (i.e., the patient is able to understand the information provided by the physician, determine how facts are relevant to their situation, use the provided information to make a decision regarding their care, and express a decision). This patient has demonstrated that she has decision-making capacity, and therefore her wishes should be followed. The surrogate health care decision-maker is only permitted to make a decision on the patient's behalf if the patient's decision-making capacity is compromised. Moreover, the patient's current decision is consistent with her decision not to undergo a colostomy 3 weeks prior. Therefore, no lifesaving measures should be undertaken. In this case, management should focus on comfort measures such as pain control and consideration of a colonic stent.
questions.hint: If a patient has decision-making capacity, their decisions regarding medical treatment should be followed.

questions.text: A 71-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of a 1-hour history of chest pain and shortness of breath. On arrival, she is disoriented but responsive. Six months ago, she received 3 stents for severe coronary heart disease. She reports that she lives alone and has little contact with her family. The admitting physician asks the patient if she has an advance directive and preferences for potential end-of-life care. The patient retrieves a living will from her purse that is consistent with her verbal confirmation that she does not wish to receive cardiopulmonary resuscitation, breathing tube placement, or defibrillation. Two days later, the patient's condition worsens, and she becomes unresponsive. The same day, the patient's neighbor comes to the hospital saying that he is a long-term friend of the patient and just heard that she was admitted to the hospital. He says that the patient's first grandchild was born 3 weeks ago. “She does not get along well with her own children, but it would mean the world to her to know that she has become a grandma. I know she would feel differently about receiving life support now that she has a grandchild.” Which of the following actions would be most appropriate if the patient needed life support?

choices.text: Ask the neighbor to verify in writing that the patient wants life support, then provide full resuscitation
Provide basic life support but do not intubate or defibrillate the patient
Provide full life support until the patient's family can be consulted to assist in the decision
Provide only comfort measures to the patient
Administer vasopressor agents as needed but do not provide other life support

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

When a patient lacks decision-making capacity or does not have a living will, directives by a close friend (e.g., the neighbor) can override a living will, but only if the friend has a durable medical power of attorney from the patient and such a decision is in line with the patient's most recently expressed wishes. In this case, there is no mention of a durable medical power of attorney, and the patient's most recent wish to not receive life support was expressed verbally to the physician. Therefore, the patient's advance directive should be followed.

B) INCORRECT:

Basic life support is a form of cardiopulmonary resuscitation, which was explicitly refused by the patient in verbal and written form and should not, therefore, be implemented.

C) INCORRECT:

If a patient without decision-making capacity cannot express his or her wishes and does not have a written living will, the patient's next of kin can serve as a surrogate decision-maker. This patient's wishes, however, have already been stated verbally and in a written advanced directive.

D) CORRECT:

A living will can only be disregarded when it is not in line with a patient's most recently expressed wishes (as stated by the patient) or when a legally appointed durable medical power of attorney (for a patient without decision-making capacity) indicates that the patient's wishes have changed since the living will was last updated. Next of kin can be surrogate decision-makers only if an advance directive is not available and there is no durable medical power of attorney. In this case, this patient has a living will available and also verbally confirmed her wishes to the physician (her verbal statement would count even in the absence of a living will). Therefore, it is not appropriate for the next of kin or a close friend to be the decision-maker in this case, and only comfort measures (e.g., pain medication) should be provided to this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Vasopressor agents are a component of cardiopulmonary resuscitation, which has been clearly rejected by the patient verbally and in her written living will. Therefore, vasopressor agents should not be administered.
questions.hint: A legal document that explicitly states the patient's wishes regarding end-of-life care is available.

questions.text: A gynecologist is approached by a close personal friend after a church service that they attended together. “You know Marc and I are going on vacation next week. I totally did not see this coming, but I am going to run out of my birth control pill. I am afraid I won't be able to get my prescription filled before we leave because the next few days will be very busy. I know this is awkward, but could you please write me a prescription just to cover the time until I am back from vacation?”. The physician has known the friend for many years and she knows that she has no personal history of serious illness. The friend is an attorney who has a hectic schedule, which the physician sympathizes with. Which of the following is the most appropriate action by the physician?

choices.text: Suggest that friend use condoms for contraception during their vacation
Inform the friend that it is never appropriate for a physician to be involved in the treatment of a friend or family member
Prescribe oral contraceptives if the friend agrees to undergo a proper physical examination
Prescribe oral contraceptives after ruling out that the friend has any contraindications, but emphasize that this is an exception
Explain that it is not appropriate to prescribe medication to a friend unless in an emergency

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Condoms are an alternative form of contraception for this patient. However, physicians should generally avoid making professional consultations to close friends and family because they can be subject to conflict between emotional relationships and objectivity.

B) INCORRECT:

Physicians should generally refrain from the treatment of family and friends because professional objectivity can be clouded by emotion. However, this principle does not apply to all situations, such as when emergency treatment is indicated.

C) INCORRECT:

Whenever possible, a thorough physical examination should be performed before prescribing any medication or initiating any treatment. However, even after a thorough physical examination, it would not be appropriate for a physician to prescribe an elective medication to a friend in this case.

D) INCORRECT:

Contraindications have to be ruled out before prescribing any medications. However, even after ruling out contraindications, it would not be appropriate for this physician to prescribe elective medication to a friend in this case.

E) CORRECT:

According to the American Medical Association (AMA) Code of Medical Ethics, self-treatment, treatment of immediate family, and treatment of close friends should only occur in emergency situations. An emotional relationship with a patient can interfere with a physician's objective judgment. Their relationship may cause the physician or patient to be uncomfortable obtaining a full history and physical exam (e.g., sexual history and genitourinary exam). It is not appropriate for the physician to provide treatment to their friend in this non-emergency situation. In this case, the physician should politely decline while explaining their concerns and help the friend to find a more appropriate physician.
questions.hint: It is important that a physician always weigh the urgency of the care they are being asked to provide with objectivity towards the patient and the situation.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy comes to the physician because of burning pain during urination for the past week. During this period, he has also had clear discharge from the penis. He recently had unprotected sex with his girlfriend, who is the same age as him. The result of a polymerase chain reaction test for Chlamydia trachomatis is positive. The patient says that his girlfriend knows about his symptoms, but he does not want his parents to be notified of his sexual activity or his positive test for a sexually transmitted infection because they do not approve of premarital sex. He adds that he wants to avoid any further conflicts with his mother, as they have been fighting recently. Which of the following is the most appropriate action by the physician?

choices.text: Prescribe medication for the patient and inform the girlfriend’s parents
Prescribe medication for the patient only if the patient’s parents give consent to treatment
Prescribe medication for the patient and inform both the patient’s parents and the girlfriend’s parents
Prescribe medication for the patient only if the patient meets the criteria for legal emancipation
Prescribe medication for the patient without notifying the patient’s parents or the girlfriend’s parents
Prescribe medication for the patient and his girlfriend and inform both the patient’s parents and the girlfriend’s parents

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Laws regarding consent in adolescent health care differ by state, but all states allow minors to consent to the evaluation and management of sexually transmitted infections (STIs); parental consent is not required. Thus, informing this patient's girlfriend's parents without his consent is a breach of confidentiality.

B) INCORRECT:

Laws regarding consent in adolescent health care differ by state, but all states allow minors to consent to the evaluation and management of sexually transmitted infections (STIs). Thus, informing this patient's parents without his consent is a breach of confidentiality, and their consent to treatment is not needed.

C) INCORRECT:

Laws regarding consent in adolescent health care differ by state, but all states allow minors to consent to the evaluation and management of sexually transmitted infections (STIs); parental consent is not required. Thus, informing this patient's parents and his girlfriend's parents without his consent is a breach of confidentiality.

D) INCORRECT:

Laws regarding consent in adolescent health care differ by state, but all states allow minors to consent to the evaluation and management of sexually transmitted infections (STIs); legal emancipation is not required.

E) CORRECT:

Laws regarding consent in adolescent health care differ by state, but all states allow minors to consent to the evaluation and management of sexually transmitted infections (STIs); parental consent is not required. This patient does not want his parents to know that he is sexually active or has an STI. Accordingly, the physician is ethically and legally obliged to keep his medical information confidential (though minors should, in general, be counseled to have open discussions about health with their parents or legal guardians). However, because this patient has a notifiable disease (Chlamydia trachomatis infection), the physician is required to report the case to a public health official.

Other exceptions to when parental consent is generally not needed for a minor to receive medical care include emergency care, care related to addiction, and care related to sexual behavior (e.g., contraception, pregnancy).

F) INCORRECT:

Laws regarding consent in adolescent health care differ by state, but all states allow minors to consent to the evaluation and management of sexually transmitted infections (STIs); parental consent is not required. Thus, informing this patient's parents and his girlfriend's parents without his consent is a breach of confidentiality. In several states, physicians can also prescribe treatment for certain sexually transmitted infections for a patient's partner even if the partner has not been evaluated by the physician.
questions.hint: There are exceptions to when consent from a parent is required before treating a minor.

questions.text: An attending physician in internal medicine publishes an important study about the efficacy of a new drug used to treat Crohn disease. She is currently treating many patients with inflammatory bowel disease who would benefit greatly from this new treatment. After the study is published, the physician receives a letter from the pharmaceutical company that manufactures the medication. The company offers her sponsorship of travel, lodging, and registration to present her research at an important international conference on inflammatory bowel disease. The company also offers her funding for a phase III trial with the new drug at the hospital where she is currently working. The company reserves the right to withhold the publication of the physician's research findings after the trial. The physician is very interested in both the drug trial and the conference, where many potential collaborators would be present that could help assist in her research. Which of the following is the most appropriate response from the attending physician?

choices.text: Reject the trial funding and accept the conference sponsorship but properly disclose the financial support.
Accept trial funding and conference sponsorship if the institutional review board gives permission.
Accept the trial funding and reject the conference sponsorship.
Reject both the offer for the trial funding and the conference sponsorship.
To avoid a potential conflict of interest, recommend that a senior resident attend the conference and lead the trial.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The American Medical Association Code of Medical Ethics states that costs related to travel and accommodation or personal expenses an attending physician incurs related to a conference or meeting should not be paid for by industry. In addition, a pharmaceutical company cannot invite a physician to present at a medical conference. Instead, the institution organizing the conference or meeting may accept commercial support (i.e., from the pharmaceutical company) and independently decide the appropriate use of its funds (e.g., content, presenters, fees, reimbursement).

B) INCORRECT:

Industry-sponsored research is permissible if there are no conflicts of interest and if the institutional review board gives permission. However, the American Medical Association (AMA) Code of Medical Ethics states that physicians should have complete autonomy over the presentation and publication of the results. This company's stipulations for trial funding jeopardizes the integrity of research. In addition, the AMA Code of Medical Ethics states that reimbursement for travel, accommodation, or other costs an attending physician incurs at a conference or meeting should not be paid for by industry. In addition, a pharmaceutical company cannot invite a physician to present at a medical conference. Instead, the institution organizing the conference or meeting may accept commercial support (i.e., from the pharmaceutical company) and independently decide the appropriate use of its funds (e.g., content, presenters, fees, reimbursement).

C) INCORRECT:

The American Medical Association (AMA) Code of Medical Ethics states that physicians should have complete autonomy over the presentation and publication of results following a clinical trial. This company's stipulations for trial funding would jeopardize the integrity of a potential research study.

D) CORRECT:

The American Medical Association Code of Medical Ethics states that a physician can accept a gift from industry only if it assists the physician's work and benefits patients. The value of any such gift should not be substantial; pens, notepads, and medical textbooks are examples of acceptable gifts. Consequently, the AMA states that a physician should not accept subsidies from industry for the purpose of underwriting the cost of continuing medical education conferences or professional meetings (e.g., travel, lodging, and registration). Moreover, a pharmaceutical company cannot invite a physician to present at a medical conference. Instead, the institution organizing the conference or meeting may accept commercial support (i.e., from the pharmaceutical company) and independently decide the appropriate use of its funds (e.g., content, presenters, fees, reimbursement).

Physician partnership with pharmaceutical companies has grown exponentially as funding in clinical research activities has expanded. While phase III drug trials are often industry-sponsored, the lead researcher should have complete responsibility for the conduct of the trial, data analysis, and research publication; even unfavorable results from the trial should be reported. The company's stipulations for trial funding jeopardizes the integrity of research. Therefore, the attending physician should not accept the trial funding. Industry-sponsored research is only permissible if there are no conflicts of interest, the institutional review board gives permission, and all sources of funding are duly disclosed.

E) INCORRECT:

The American Medical Association Code of Medical Ethics permits industry to provide funds (e.g., grants) to academic/training institutions in order to help medical students, residents, and fellows attend an important medical conference. However, to avoid any conflict of interest, the training institution (not an attending physician) where trainees are attending medical school or completing their residency or fellowship must independently select the recipients. In addition, financial assistance should not be given directly from the industry to the attendees. Moreover, a licensed physician must lead a drug trial; it would be inappropriate for a senior resident, who has not yet completed training, to lead a drug trial.
questions.hint: Patients can benefit from collaboration between pharmaceutical companies and physicians. However, clinical research guidelines should be followed to protect the integrity of research, objectivity of the physician's judgment, and general welfare of patients.

questions.text: A 1-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents for a well-child examination. She is scheduled to receive vaccinations against hepatitis A, measles, mumps, rubella, and varicella. She does not have a fever or a history of serious illness. The physician reviews the recommended immunization schedule with the parents during the visit. They agree to all vaccinations except the one against varicella. When asked about their reason for refusing the varicella vaccine, the father says, “It has nothing to do with the cost. We simply believe that the vaccine is unnecessary. We both had chickenpox as children, and it was no problem. Also, we are homeschooling.” The physician informs the parents of the risks of not vaccinating their daughter against varicella, including the sequelae of chickenpox infection in adults. The parents thank the physician for the information but decline the varicella vaccine for now. Which of the following is the most appropriate action by the physician at this time?

choices.text: Respect the parents' decision and defer discussion on varicella vaccination until the patient reaches the age of majority
Inform the parents about the physician's liability for medical negligence and terminate the physician-patient relationship
Recommend resources on varicella vaccination and at the next visit ask the parents about administering the vaccination
Accept the parents' decision but report the varicella vaccination refusal to the local public health agency
Inform child protective services about the potential for child neglect

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The physician should respect the parents' decision to not vaccinate their child, as they are free to make decisions about their child's medical care unless that decision puts the child at substantial risk of harm. However, the physician should not defer the discussion until the girl reaches the age of majority. Instead, he or she should attempt to convince the parents of the merits of vaccination and take advantage of their ongoing, respectful relationship to address the refused vaccination at subsequent visits.

B) INCORRECT:

The physician may be concerned about his or her liability for medical negligence based on treating a child who did not receive a recommended vaccine. This can be addressed by documenting the conversation with the parents about the risks and benefits of vaccinating and not vaccinating and the parents' refusal. Physicians should avoid terminating the physician-patient relationship just because parents refuse to vaccinate their child. This decision should be made only if a substantial level of conflict develops and compromises the physician-patient relationship. Also, if the physician terminates the relationship, he or she needs to provide sufficient notice so that another health care provider can be found.

C) CORRECT:

The physician's role in situations in which parents refuse vaccination for their child should be to explore parental concerns, provide the parents with reliable information about the risks and benefits of vaccination, and attempt to correct misinformation so the parents can make an informed decision. The topic should then be revisited at the next visit. If the parents still refuse vaccination after further discussion, the physician must respect the decision and most situations do not require that coercive measure be taken (e.g., reporting the refusal to the public health agency, involving state agencies to override the parents' decision on the premise of medical neglect, informing child protective services). Coercive measures are usually only required if there is a significant risk of serious harm to the child and/or to others (e.g., diseases with very high morbidity and mortality, vaccines targeting epidemic disease).

D) INCORRECT:

Coercive measures like reporting the parents' decision to not vaccinate their child to the local public health agency are usually only justified if that decision poses a significant risk of harm to the child or others. In this case, since it is a varicella immunization, it does not pose a significant risk because the population is highly immunized and the prevalence of the disease is low. Therefore, it is not necessary to report this situation to the public health agency.

E) INCORRECT:

Informing child protective services would not be appropriate for this patient or in most cases of vaccination refusal. The physician should only inform child protective services about the potential for child neglect if the decision to not vaccinate puts the child at substantial risk of harm (e.g., refusing the tetanus vaccine in a child who has a puncture wound that is deep and contaminated), which is not the case here.
questions.hint: It is important to remember that, in an ongoing, respectful relationship between the physician and the parents, there is usually more than one opportunity to talk about a vaccination that is refused.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman comes to the family physician for a routine health maintenance examination. The patient and her family, including her mother and father, have all been in the physician's care for the past 20 years, and the patient regularly accompanies her parents to their appointments. During the examination, the patient mentions that she is concerned that her 70-year-old father has recently bought a parcel of land and now wants to build a new home on it. Her father worked as a contractor for 30 years before going into retirement and plans to build the house himself with only minor help from other contractors. The patient explains that she is worried her father will injure himself while working on the house and “dig himself into a financial hole.” She asks the physician whether he could speak to her father about his plans and explain to him that these would be too much of a physical and financial risk for a person of his age. Which of the following is the most appropriate statement by the physician at this time?

choices.text: "I encourage you to speak to your father directly about your concerns. If you're unable to resolve the situation on your own, I can refer you to a family therapist."
"I believe this constitutes a legal dispute. As such, I think you should contact a lawyer."
"I must admit that I agree with your concerns. I will bring this up when I have the next appointment with your father."
"I understand you are concerned, but it is your father's right to make such decisions. You should try to support him in his decision."
"I understand you are concerned, but I should not be involved in such family matters, especially if they are not directly related to your father's medical care."

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Clinicians who provide care for multiple members of the same family are sometimes confronted with family conflicts. Physicians should not take sides since it compromises at least one clinician-patient relationship. The clinician should encourage conflict resolution because impaired family relationships can negatively impact health outcomes. If conflicts between family members cannot be resolved, the clinician can suggest referral to a family therapist.

Clinicians may need to intervene in family conflicts involving suspected abuse.

B) INCORRECT:

The patient's concern for her father's physical and financial wellbeing does not constitute a legal dispute, so this response would not be appropriate.

C) INCORRECT:

The physician cannot agree with the patient's concerns because by doing so the physician takes sides in a family conflict; the physician must remain neutral. The physician also cannot mention the daughter's concerns in the next appointment with the father, because doing so would breach the obligation of confidentiality to the daughter.

D) INCORRECT:

This would not be an appropriate response to the patient's request, because the physician is giving their personal opinion about this family conflict and indirectly blaming this patient for not supporting her father. The physician should attempt to stay neutral and suggest other ways to deal with this family issue.

E) INCORRECT:

This response is partially correct because the physician's involvement in the family conflict is not directly related to the patient's medical care. However, this is not the most appropriate response because, besides being neutral, the physician should further advise the patient to seek conflict resolution.
questions.hint: This physician has an obligation of confidentiality, beneficence, and autonomy to both of his patients; fulfilling this relative's request could violate the autonomy principle and compromise a physician-patient relationship.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. He has nontremor-dominant Parkinson disease that was diagnosed at the age of 68 after developing progressive bradykinesia and rigidity. He lives alone following the death of his wife 2 years ago. The patient's son, daughter-in-law, and grandchildren live nearby and help him with daily activities. Current medications include levodopa, carbidopa, and entacapone. He appears well. Neurologic examination shows mild hypomimia, bradydiadochokinesia, shortened steps, and mild gait shuffling. During the examination, the patient mentions that he drove himself to his appointment today because he does not want to feel like a burden on his son. The physician is concerned that the patient's illness and medications potentially impair his driving skills. The patient stresses that he has never had an accident in his life and is a very safe driver. He also states that he has felt isolated since his wife's passing and likes to meet up with old friends at a local bar. Which of the following is the most appropriate reaction by the physician?

choices.text: "You should not feel that you are a burden on your son. I'm sure he will be happy to drive you."
"I understand that you need your car to stay mobile, but without an official evaluation of your driving capacity, you should not be driving anywhere."
"I have a duty to public safety and unfortunately, I must inform the police that you are still driving."
"I would advise you to stop driving, but I cannot tell you what to do. Just be aware that it is solely your responsibility if something bad happens."
"I understand this is a difficult situation for you, but I have to ask you to surrender your driver's license now."

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A physician should encourage patients to communicate with their family members and seek help when necessary. However, it is inappropriate for the physician to presume that the patient's son would be willing to drive for the patient. The physician should instead explore the patient's reasons for feeling like a burden on his son, rather than simply instructing him not to feel this way. Moreover, in this case, it is critical to inform the patient that his current condition impairs his ability to drive safely; a different reaction would, therefore, be appropriate.

B) CORRECT:

Irrespective of state laws, if a physician believes that a patient cannot drive safely, the physician must share their concerns with the patient and ask them to stop driving until they have been evaluated and treated by a driver rehabilitation specialist. Alternatively, the patient can be recleared for driving by the state licensing authority (e.g., Department of Motor Vehicles). However, the laws for reporting impaired drivers differ between states.

Most states have voluntary reporting laws, under which a physician is not required to disclose a patient's driving impairment to the state licensing authority but are protected from a breach of patient confidentiality if they do so. Some states have mandatory reporting laws, which require physicians to report any patient with driving impairment to the state licensing authority. In states with voluntary or mandatory reporting laws, the physician can be held liable for a motor vehicle accident involving the impaired driver if the physician does not report the driving impairment. A few states do not have any reporting laws and require the physician to obtain the patient's consent before disclosing driving impairment to the authorities. In these states, the physician cannot be held liable for a motor vehicle accident involving the impaired driver if the physician does not have consent to disclose driver impairment.

C) INCORRECT:

In states with mandatory reporting laws, the physician has an obligation to report patients with conditions that impair driving ability. However, the state licensing authority (e.g., Department of Motor Vehicles) rather than the police should be informed in this scenario. The physician needs to inform the police only if the patient divulges a criminal act to the physician (e.g., hit-and-run, alcohol-related car accident).

D) INCORRECT:

When the patient has a condition that limits their ability to drive safely, the physician must advise the patient to stop driving. However, in most states, if the patient continues to drive against medical advice and the physician does not report the patient to state licensing authorities, the physician can also be held liable for injuries that occur from a motor vehicle accident involving the patient.

E) INCORRECT:

The physician cannot ask a patient to surrender their driver's license. The state licensing authorities (e.g., Department of Motor Vehicles) rather than a physician should determine the patient's inability to drive safely.
questions.hint: The physician must balance responsibility to public safety with the welfare of the individual patient.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is admitted to the hospital for a follow-up evaluation of a spinal lesion identified during surveillance imaging. One year ago, he had tonsillar squamous cell carcinoma treated with chemotherapy and radiation therapy. He undergoes a CT-guided needle biopsy of the spinal lesion and is awaiting the pathology result. A medical student, who is part of the team involved in the patient's care, sees the patient in the hospital cafeteria. The student has just reviewed the patient's spinal biopsy result, which is consistent with metastatic squamous cell carcinoma of oropharyngeal origin. The patient approaches the student in the cafeteria and asks if the biopsy result has come back. Which of the following is the most appropriate response?

choices.text: "I believe the biopsy showed cancer, but I have to review the result with the rest of the team to confirm."
"Unfortunately, the biopsy is consistent with cancer and your prognosis is poor since it indicates metastasis."
"The result is back but I need to discuss it with the team before I can give you accurate information."
"I do not know if the biopsy result is back but I will get back to you."
"Let's go back to your room so it's more private and I will go over the result with you."

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although the student is acknowledging the need to discuss with the team, they should not disclose the result to the patient before consulting with the senior team members. In addition, the patient's medical information should not be shared in a public space such as the hospital cafeteria. Finally, this can cause psychological harm to the patient as he will likely be worried the whole time while waiting for the confirmation of the results.

B) INCORRECT:

Although the student already knows the result of the biopsy and it is important to be honest with the patient, it is unlikely that the student can provide the most accurate and complete information about the topic. Therefore, it would not be appropriate for the student to disclose the information to the patient in this situation. Moreover, medical information should not be disclosed in public spaces such as the hospital cafeteria.

C) CORRECT:

Medical students are often confronted with situations in which patients ask them to disclose diagnostic workup, treatment options, or information on prognosis. The result of the biopsy should not be disclosed until the student is able to discuss it with senior members of the team, because medical students are not qualified to provide the most accurate and detailed information about complex topics. The student must also be honest with the patient, acknowledging that the information requested is available and explaining why its disclosure is being withheld. Finally, the cafeteria is not an appropriate environment to deliver clinical information to the patient. Clinical information should be disclosed in an environment in which privacy, time, and emotional support can be ensured.

D) INCORRECT:

The student must be honest with the patient, and they already know the result of the patient's biopsy. Lying to the patient violates the principle of honesty.

E) INCORRECT:

When disclosing a patient's medical information, one should look for an appropriate environment to deliver it to the patient, in which privacy, time, and emotional support can be ensured. However, it is not appropriate for the student to disclose the results at this time because medical students are not qualified to provide the most accurate and complete information about complex topics.
questions.hint: The student should act in the best interest of the patient while also being honest with him.

questions.text: A 39-year-old woman is examined in the intensive care unit 45 minutes after she sustained a head injury in a high-speed motor vehicle collision. Her pupils are dilated and not reactive to light. She is unresponsive to noxious stimuli. CT scan of the head shows a massive intracranial bleed. After a brain death examination and an apnea test, the patient is declared brain dead. The patient has no living will or advance directives regarding organ donation and was legally competent before her death. She is survived by her 17-year-old son, elder brother, and parents. Her son is currently on a camping trip outside the country. The physician informs the local organ procurement organization, and a representative from the organization inquires with the family about donating the deceased's organs. The patient's brother permits organ donation, whereas her parents strongly disagree. The physician and the representative encourage a family meeting, but the family cannot reach an agreement on the patient's most likely wish regarding organ donation. The hospital ethics committee is convened and recommends adhering to the state law in this case. In most states, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management regarding organ donation?

choices.text: Encourage another family meeting with a social worker
Initiate organ procurement procedures
Request a court-appointed guardian
Do not proceed with organ donation
Request the patient’s son to intercede and make a decision

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

If there is a disagreement between the next of kin on the most appropriate course of action, it is appropriate for the physician to first encourage a meeting between disagreeing family members with the aim of reaching an agreement about what the deceased would have desired. However, such a meeting has already been arranged, and there are no grounds to assume that a second meeting with a social worker would provide further clarification. Most states generally establish a clear hierarchy for who would be assigned as the SDM among the next of kin.

B) INCORRECT:

It would be appropriate to proceed with the organ procurement process if the parents had consented to organ donation because parents are generally considered the highest priority SDMs after spouses. In this scenario, a different action is appropriate in most states.

C) INCORRECT:

It is appropriate to request a court-appointed guardian for a patient who lacks the capacity to make medical decisions when there is no medical power of attorney or next of kin available to serve as the SDM. In this scenario, the patient has multiple family members involved, some of whom qualify to be SDMs, so it would not be necessary to request a court-appointed guardian.

D) CORRECT:

If the patient lacks decision-making capacity or is deceased and does not have advance directives, a self-appointed SDM, or court-appointed SDM, the next of kin becomes their SDM. Most states have established a hierarchy to assign a next of kin as the SDM, although the order may vary from state to state. Spouses are most often listed first, followed by adult children, parents, adult siblings, and close friends. Fiancés and nonlegal partners are not considered spouses in most states, and adulthood is typically defined as 18 years of age. In this case, the patient's parents, who are not in favor of organ donation, would serve as this patient's representatives. The organ donation process should therefore be stopped.

E) INCORRECT:

Although mature or emancipated minors can, in some states, under rare circumstances, be appointed as SDMs, individuals under 18 years of age are generally considered legally incompetent to make medical decisions. This patient's son is 17 years of age and not considered a mature or emancipated minor, so another person would be designated as the SDM.
questions.hint: In the absence of an oral or written advance directive for a deceased individual, a surrogate decision-maker (SDM) should be designated to act in their best interest. An SDM may be designated by a patient prior to loss of capacity (e.g., durable medical power of attorney), legally appointed (a court-appointed guardian), or appointed via default sequence among the next of kin.

questions.text: A 31-year-old homeless and uninsured man is brought to the emergency department because he was found agitated and yelling for help. He is well known to the emergency department and has been in and out of the hospital 6 times in the past month for various issues. He has used up his allotted health care assistance program limit and has an outstanding debt to the hospital. When the physician speaks to him, the man states that he just used some drugs that his friend gave him and now has chest pain. Except for illicit drug use, his past medical history is unknown. He appears unkempt. He is diaphoretic and malodorous but oriented to time, place, and person. Which of the following is the most appropriate statement by the physician?

choices.text: "We will need to set up health insurance coverage for you with the county healthcare assistance program before treating you."
"We will treat you to the best of our ability, but we will not be liable in the event of medical negligence."
"We will check your vital signs and do a workup of your chest pain, but we will have to deny further treatment if the cause of your chest pain is not a medical emergency."
"We will help you get transferred to the nearest hospital, but we cannot treat you since you have used up your allotted health care assistance program limit at our hospital."
"We will treat you only if you commit to enrolling in a drug rehabilitation program."

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

According to the Emergency Medical Treatment and Labor Act (EMTALA), any hospital with an emergency department is legally obligated to evaluate and stabilize an acute medical emergency (e.g., ACS), regardless of the patient's health insurance coverage. Once the patient is stabilized, it would be appropriate to assist him in finding additional healthcare coverage (e.g., through a county healthcare assistance program for low-income patients).

B) INCORRECT:

According to the Emergency Medical Treatment and Labor Act (EMTALA), any hospital with an emergency department is legally obligated to evaluate and stabilize an acute medical emergency (e.g., ACS). The hospital and/or treating physician may still be held liable in the event of medical negligence.

C) CORRECT:

According to the Emergency Medical Treatment and Labor Act (EMTALA), any hospital with an emergency department is obligated to screen for emergency medical conditions if requested and, if such a condition exists, provide treatment until that condition is stabilized. Failure to diagnose and treat ACS would endanger this patient's life. The EMTALA defines an emergency medical condition as a medical condition that manifests with acute symptoms (including pain and labor contractions) that are sufficiently severe to (i) place the health of the individual or unborn child in serious jeopardy, (ii) seriously impair bodily functions, or (iii) cause serious dysfunction of an organ or body part.

D) INCORRECT:

According to the Emergency Medical Treatment and Labor Act (EMTALA), any hospital with an emergency department is legally obligated to evaluate and stabilize an acute medical emergency (e.g., ACS), regardless of the patient's financial limitations. Transferring the patient to another hospital is appropriate if the hospital is not equipped or staffed to properly evaluate and treat a patient's condition.

E) INCORRECT:

According to the Emergency Medical Treatment and Labor Act (EMTALA), any hospital with an emergency department is legally obligated to evaluate and stabilize an acute medical emergency (e.g., ACS), regardless of the patient's willingness to participate in a drug rehabilitation program. Once the patient is stabilized, it is appropriate to assist him in enrolling in such a program.
questions.hint: This patient with chest pain and diaphoresis might have acute coronary syndrome (ACS), which is a potentially life-threatening condition.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman with recently diagnosed acute myelocytic leukemia (AML) comes to a physician-investigator for a follow-up visit. Two months ago, she was enrolled in a randomized, single-blind, active-control equivalence trial involving an experimental combination chemotherapy regimen for AML. At every monthly visit, the study participants undergo chemotherapy along with a clinical evaluation and laboratory workup. The study participants are given prorated compensation following each visit. There is no additional compensation for completing the study. She has completed two of the four planned monthly cycles. On examination today, she appears tired but is in no apparent distress. During the evaluation, she says that she wants to “continue medical treatments” but would like to “withdraw from the study.” In addition to asking her why she wants to withdraw, which of the following is the most appropriate action by the physician-investigator concerning the participant's request?

choices.text: Consult the institutional review board overseeing the trial
Unblind the participant by revealing which group she was in
Destroy all clinical and diagnostic data collected on the participant so far
Ask the participant if she is willing to undergo any follow-up evaluation
Offer remaining compensation for subsequent visits

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

All clinical trials are required to have institutional review board (IRB) approval before enrolling participants and conducting research. The IRB should be notified in the event of a protocol deviation (e.g., including a participant who does not meet the required criteria, dosing error) or adverse event. Although study withdrawal should be documented, participants are allowed to withdraw from studies without prior consultation with the IRB.

B) INCORRECT:

The protocol for unblinding is determined by the institutional review board at the beginning of a trial. Specific circumstances, such as a subject's pregnancy or adverse events that affect safety, may require unblinding participants. Investigators may also decide to unblind participants after completion of the trial. However, withdrawal from a study is not an obligatory reason to unblind the participant and another action is more appropriate.

C) INCORRECT:

Study participants may withdraw at any time, and all data gathered about them should be secured. To ensure patient confidentiality, it may be further necessary to anonymize the data. However, the FDA and OHRP guidelines for clinical drug trials stipulate that all data collected prior to withdrawal must remain in the study database to ensure validity of the research and enable intention-to-treat analysis if needed.

D) CORRECT:

A participant has a right to withdraw from a clinical trial at any time. The investigator should accept the decision without attempting to influence the participant in any way but may inquire about the reason for withdrawal to identify any potential risks or adverse events. In addition, the investigator should clarify whether the participant wants to withdraw completely (i.e., from all aspects of the study including follow-up) or only partially. Follow-up is important for ensuring the validity of the research and identifying adverse events that could negatively affect other participants. Informed consent on partial participation should be obtained. In the event of complete withdrawal, the participant should not be contacted for further study-related activities, and no additional information should be collected about them. The information collected to date may be kept.

E) INCORRECT:

The type of compensation is determined prior to study enrollment and should be uniformly applicable to all participants. Prorated compensation is used for studies involving multiple visits. This compensation model equitably distributes compensation among participants and pays participants a predetermined amount for each procedure and/or visit. With this compensation model, a participant who wishes to withdraw completely from the study should not be denied compensation that they have already earned but should not be offered compensation for the subsequent visits because such an action may go against the principle of justice for the other participants and risks imposing an element of undue influence on the withdrawing participant to remain (either completely or partially) in the study. Another action is necessary before discussing compensation.

Regardless of the type of compensation model used, a study participant may be eligible for additional compensation if they experienced adverse events from the intervention.
questions.hint: This patient wants to discontinue her participation in a human subjects research study. The investigator should follow the guidelines set forth by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) and the Office for Human Research Protections (OHRP).

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents for a routine health examination. According to the patient's mother, the boy has been more withdrawn lately and has also lost some weight, which she finds “suspicious.” Their family moved from a different state 6 months ago. The boy has some difficulty making friends at the new school but has good academic performance. He enjoys playing drums and has a good appetite. The patient says he tried beer before but does not smoke cigarettes or use illicit drugs. His vital signs are normal. Physical and mental status examinations show no abnormalities. The physician reassures the parents that their son is experiencing a normal stress reaction. At the end of the visit, the patient's mother asks if she could talk to the physician in private. When left alone with the physician, the mother says: “I think my son is lying about the drug use. Could you please run a drug test on him but tell him it is just a routine laboratory test?” Which of the following is the most appropriate response by the physician?

choices.text: "We can perform this test only if you as a parent sign a liability waiver."
"I understand your concern and will schedule the test for our next appointment."
"I do not think your son is using drugs, since his examination showed no abnormalities."
"I cannot lie to your son about the nature of the test. Why do you think your son is lying about the drug use?"
"I could do this, but I think it would be better if you discussed your concerns with your son first."

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

There is no liability waiver applicable for the scenario presented in this case.

B) INCORRECT:

Empathetic communication with a patient and/or their family promotes a trusting relationship, which can ultimately improve the care of the patient. However, physicians are legally and ethically obliged to tell their patients the truth, and deceiving the patient would be inappropriate.

C) INCORRECT:

This response is prematurely dismissive of the parent's concerns and does not allow for investigation of the underlying reason for her concerns. Moreover, a normal physical and mental examination cannot rule out substance use disorders.

D) CORRECT:

Physicians are legally and ethically obliged to tell their patients the truth. Lying to a patient will likely damage the physician-patient relationship and possibly impede future care. Moreover, parental consent for medical care of an unemancipated minor is not required in matters of sex (e.g., contraception, pregnancy care except for abortion in most states, STIs) or addiction care; in these instances, minors can receive care without their parent's knowledge or consent.
